post: Kentish Town station on the Northern line is open for business!

comment.body:
# Upvote/Downvote reminder

Like this image or appreciate it being posted? Upvote it and show it some love! Don't like it? Just downvote and move on. 

*Upvoting or downvoting images it the best way to control what you see on your feed and what gets to the top of the subreddit*


*I am a bot, and this action was performed automatically. Please [contact the moderators of this subreddit](/message/compose/?to=/r/london) if you have any questions or concerns.*
I was there yesterday and it was closed. I have to take the tube there again this morning. I shall report back on the veracity of this post
Iâ€™ve just fucking moved away from there! One and a half years of walking over the hill to Tufnell Park *grumble grumble*
Is itâ€¦ actually!?
Straight to Rio's!
Kentish Town station is the tube's very own HS2.
https://i.redd.it/24sj1lud7k8e1.gif
Great news if theyâ€™ve finally managed to get it done. I didnâ€™t realise how often I used this station and the walk up to Tufnell Park adds more time than I thought.
They couldâ€™ve made it look nicer at least after such a longer closureâ€¦.
Suspicious... I don't buy it.

Was it closed as long as Mornington Crescent? I seem to remember that for years of my childhood, MC was always closed - had a red X over it on the tube map. When it was eventually reopened it seemed like something mythical had happened.

Haha I have to see it to believe it ðŸ˜… 

What was the original opening date again?
I used to live just up the road from there from 96-99, I'm tempted to have a festive visit to relive old times.

From what Iâ€™m aware, the works done were:

Refitting new escalators 

Gutting and refitting the ticket hall with more card reading access points

Removing the ticket office (which was closed anyway)

Refitting and retiling the platforms

Plus unexpected structural problems discovered whilst removing the old knackered escalators 


I used to go past it every morning on the tube from Tufnell Park. One week the platforms had all been graffitied which obviously needed removing. It feels like a lot of work to me, especially knowing the work that goes in to removing and replacing the escalators in confined spaces. But what do I know. The longer it was closed, the more revenue they lost, presumably.
Oh yeah, suuuure. And I bet Euston has finally been renovated into something that doesn't resemble a complete hellscape too?
The station may be open, but are the trains running?
what makes the town Kentish then?
How.... unimpressive. I'm guessing those escalator people were paid hourly, because nothing else seems to have been going on.
Is Kentish town a nice place to live with a small kid?

Went through it this morning

I can't for the life of me figure out what took 18 months of work. Looks the same
Such an incredible disappointment. Nothing has changed and, if anything, itâ€™s dirtier than before.
![gif](giphy|OXDYQGXYJd5eY434fZ)
If so whatâ€™s the point it literally closes again in 2 days ðŸ˜‚
The most anticipated reveal in human history. Marvel could never.
It was due to open today, specifically.
Please let us know!
It is. https://tfl.gov.uk/travel-information/improvements-and-projects/kentish-town-station-closure

Yes. 

https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cvg6emg146vo
Nothing like festive dip with 'friends' in the Plunge Pool!
Looks a lot cleaner in that photo than it did before to me
2 years of work just to put some escalators in and do some decor, brilliant efficiency. Apparently it was 6-12 months late too.

Mornington Crescent was closed for six years! 1992 to 1998. Partly because it was in so much worse condition than Kentish Town - needed entirely new lifts, with an old lift being converted into a staircase, a new booking hall with ticket gates, complete rewiring with new fire system, CCTV, emergency call points, restoring heritage tiling, fixing all the leaks etc. 

But also frankly London Transport (as it was back then) didn't have any money, and with Camden, Euston and Warren Street nearby, it wasn't a huge catchment area that was affected so they could get away with it for longer.
It was originally meant to open in [June](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cvg6emg146vo).
4BC
July I think.
Yes.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentish_Town#Toponymy
2 years work btw, fully taxpayer funded.

I seem to remember that they also found some structural problems with floors and ceilings when they dismantled the escalators so they had to do some extra work. 

In fact I just found a mention of this here: https://tfl.gov.uk/travel-information/improvements-and-projects/kentish-town-station-closure
Yes. I think it is a nice area.
Itâ€™s open!!
Tis open indeed! Exiting it now
The bottomless seafood platter buffet is to die for
Exactly!
Roughly 6 months, originally, it was supposed to open summer 2024

It's a 20 minute walk from Camden to Euston station. Crazy to think that there wasn't enough money floating about to refurbish a station on the Zone 1/2 border. The reason it was shut for 6 years is just a money issue. I doubt it would have taken 6 years to fix if the money was there when it broke.

But yeah, it just seems to conjure up a time when there was less money floating around in London I guess, before the property boom, before every pub was converted to flats, when you still had dereliction in parts of central London and a tube station like this could literally sit disused for SIX years!

Classic British timeliness... Reminds me of my local train station which took a 9 weeks to fix an automatic door.

And 3 months to fix the lift.
well that's boring. I was hoping the locals all eat Gypsy Tart or something
Worthy of a Peter Jackson 3-part epic
Yayyyy!!! Thank youuuu
At Rio's?!
You go there top less as well.

Part 3 is me realising this was posted by /u/HighburyAndIslington and profusely apologising for calling into question the veracity of the post. On initial glance I had assumed it was the thumbnail of an article. I would have never doubted had I known it was coming from the legend himself.
